data.text: Awesome looking bike, but not a monstercross being that its a SC Chameleon MTB frame with a rigid fork and dropbars. Monstercross is a CX frame stuff with bigger tires than spec and dirt drop handlebars.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: thank you. it‚Äôs a Highball frame. My understanding of a monstercross is‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs an mtb frame with either a rigid or suspended fork with mtb tyres that you customise by putting drop bars, with road shifters and whatever componentry works for the drivetrain. While CX is itself a CX bike that you can easily buy from bike stores. MX bikes are built to whatever your standards maybe.. And that is my standard..
data.author: FJ Baguna

data.text: Yeah Monstercross predates the "gravel" scene, it was never a MTB frame as that was another sub-genre "dropbar MTB". It was cross bikes utilizing the frame space for mud clearance to put larger than stock tires 38-50c or bigger....bit of randonneuring and MTB chops on a CX bike. Examples of the OG "Monstercross" were like the Singular Peregrine, Soma Double Cross and many others..
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: thanks for the inputs..
data.author: FJ Baguna

data.text: this thing is soooo cool! Congratulations on a fantastic build. It looks amazing
data.author: Tim McMullen

data.text: On a side note, I completely forgot that SC made an aluminum Highball. I've owned a SC bike since '99 with my first full suspension: Superlight. I sold off my Tallboy v1 in the gap when Santa Cruz didn't have anything in the gap between 100mm and 145mm with the Hightower and switched to Ibis but all during the time I still have my Blur Carbon v1 26" and my '16 Chameleon...so special place in my soul for that brand having owned 9 SC bikes over the years!

data.author: Ben Sherratt

data.text: ... with fenders awesome. I was not a fender person and only put wrap around street scrapers on my custom show builds. When I got my Surley Midnight Special my LBS manager gave me his fenders for free. I put them on and I didn't like them. Then I got caught in a annoying rain and then the light went on. Don't you be touching my fenders. My bike is perfect for my local riding. Now retired I use my bike for errands and beyond. I gas up my van once a month or longer. The only thing that bothers me is the lowest gear with a load is not quite enough and would like to drop maybe just one tooth on the chainring and then ride like it was meant to be.

data.author: Ruben Jr Santos

data.text: SRAM 10sp stuff is fully compatible with each other. The only mod that needs to be made is if you're using road shifters with MTB deraileur, you're going to a barrel adjuster somewhere. I have a bike setup with Rival shifters and GX rear derailleur, just put an in-line barrel adjuster on the cable inlet of the RD. It's also setup with a Shimano SLX setup with a narrow-wide 42T ring and 11-36 SRAM MTB cassette. Sorry no pics for that, but here is a pic of my R7000 105 using a XT 11-40 cassette...not that much of a mullet or MTB parts on a gravel bike...although I am using a 50mm MTB stem for the handlebars and 29x2.1 Vittoria Terreno XC tires.ü§∑
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: you have a neat set up.. may I ask what size is your bike?
data.author: Ruben Jr Santos

data.text: 50cm Its a '18 Ridley X-trail 105. However, on inspection of the new Ridley Kanzo A...they're exactly the same frame new paint, ‚Ç¨500 price hike and downgrade the groupset from 105 11sp to GRX 400 10sp. I don't have a good picture of the current setup because I use it to commute into work nearly every day...The current tires are American Classic Kimberlite 700x50, Replaced the Linskey titanium setback post to a Cane Creek eeSilk Plus, WolfTooth Road Link with 11-42 cassette, AGU half frame bag, and run either Ortlieb Gravel Packs with a rack or an Ortlieb 16L saddlebag along with an Ortlieb Handlebar Pack QR. The bars are Zipp ADVR 70 46cm.
